docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman questioned his opponent's commitment to Israel at a fund-raiser in Manhattan yesterday, saying he had received important support from several Democrats who have been critical of Israel. Speaking to a largely Jewish group of a few dozen supporters, Mr. Lieberman said that Ned Lamont, who defeated him in the Democratic primary, had been ''surrounded by people who are either naïve or are isolationists or, frankly, some more explicitly against Israel.''

headline.main: Lieberman Queries Lamont Over Commitment to Israel

docs.abstract: Sen Joseph I Lieberman questions commitment of Democratic opponent Ned Lamont to Israel, pointing out Lamont's affiliation with Rep Maxine Waters, who voted against resolution condemning Hezbollah for attacking Israel during war in Lebanon; Lieberman also makes pointed remarks about Lamont's affiliation with Al Sharpton, whom he describes as divisive; Lamont campaign calls Lieberman's remarks 'gutter politics'; photos (M)

byline.original: By JENNIFER MEDINA; Sarah Kershaw and Stacey Stowe contributed reporting

docs.lead_paragraph: Years of tough oversight and steep fines have left street vendors in Lower Manhattan in a precarious economic state, barely able to make a living at a time when most vendors are educated, law-abiding immigrants who increasingly support large families both overseas and locally, according to a report yesterday by the Urban Justice Center.

headline.main: For Some Pushcart Vendors, Grim Outlook Is Revealed
